articles.title: Beyond Borders: Why the Muslim World Needs a Unified Digital Payments System
articles.author: Guest Contributor
articles.content:
The Fragmentation Problem

When a Malaysian entrepreneur wants to purchase textiles from an Indonesian supplier, or when a Saudi charity seeks to transfer funds to a relief organization in Bangladesh, they encounter a labyrinth of intermediaries, currency conversions, and transaction fees that can consume up to 7% of the transfer value. This inefficiency stands in stark contrast to the seamless digital payment systems emerging within individual nations, and represents a missed opportunity for the 1.8 billion Muslims across 57 Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) member states.

The World Bank estimates that remittances to OIC countries exceeded $400 billion in 2023, with intra-OIC trade valued at approximately $600 billion annually. Yet these massive flows remain shackled by fragmented payment infrastructures that rely heavily on Western-dominated networks like SWIFT, Visa, and Mastercard. The average cost of sending remittances within OIC countries stands at 6.8%, nearly double the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal target of 3%. This represents an annual drain of over $27 billion—resources that could otherwise fuel economic development, poverty alleviation, and entrepreneurship across the Muslim world.

The Islamic Imperative for Economic Cooperation

The case for a unified OIC digital payments infrastructure extends beyond mere economics into the realm of Islamic principle. The Quran explicitly encourages cooperation among believers: "And cooperate in righteousness and piety, but do not cooperate in sin and aggression" (5:2). Economic integration that facilitates halal commerce, reduces exploitation through excessive fees, and strengthens the collective capacity of Muslim nations represents a contemporary application of this divine directive.

The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) established the first Islamic state in Medina with a unified market system that eliminated arbitrary barriers to trade among diverse tribes. His prohibition of najash (artificial price inflation) and his emphasis on transparency in commercial transactions provide timeless principles for modern payment systems. A unified digital infrastructure could embed these Shariah-compliant principles at the architectural level, ensuring that every transaction across the Muslim world adheres to Islamic commercial ethics.

Moreover, the Islamic concept of the ummah—the global community of believers—calls for practical solidarity beyond rhetorical unity. When Turkish citizens face currency crises or when Pakistani businesses struggle with dollar shortages, a shared payment infrastructure could provide resilience through diversified settlement mechanisms and reduced dependence on external financial powers.

Technical Blueprint and Existing Models

The technological foundation for such a system already exists. Several models offer instructive precedents. The European Union's SEPA (Single Euro Payments Area) enables 36 countries to process euro transactions as seamlessly as domestic payments. China's Cross-Border Interbank Payment System (CIPS) has processed over $13 trillion in transactions since 2015, demonstrating how emerging economies can build alternative payment rails. India's Unified Payments Interface (UPI) has revolutionized domestic payments with over 10 billion monthly transactions, and is now expanding internationally.

An OIC digital payments infrastructure could leverage distributed ledger technology to create a decentralized yet interoperable network. The Islamic Development Bank (IsDB), with its $150 billion in assets and presence across member states, could serve as the coordinating institution. The system would require three core components: a standardized messaging protocol for payment instructions; a multilateral settlement mechanism supporting multiple currencies and potentially a digital Islamic settlement token; and shared compliance frameworks ensuring Shariah adherence and anti-money laundering standards.

Malaysia's success with DuitNow and the UAE's leadership in central bank digital currencies provide proof of concept within OIC nations. Indonesia's GPN (National Payment Gateway) and Turkey's TROY card system demonstrate the political will to build sovereign payment infrastructure. The challenge lies not in technical capability but in diplomatic coordination and commitment to shared infrastructure over purely national systems.

Addressing the Counterarguments

Critics reasonably point to the OIC's historical difficulty in implementing collective initiatives. The organization's mixed record on political coordination, they argue, suggests economic integration may prove equally elusive. Furthermore, wealthier Gulf states may question whether subsidizing payment infrastructure for poorer member nations serves their interests, while countries like Turkey and Malaysia might resist systems that compromise their technological sovereignty.

These concerns merit serious consideration but not capitulation. Unlike political disputes where zero-sum dynamics prevail, payment infrastructure creates positive-sum outcomes. Saudi Arabia and the UAE would benefit from reduced transaction costs with their largest trading partners and labor-sending countries. Turkey's technology sector could provide expertise and services to the network. Malaysia could position itself as a Shariah-compliance hub for the system.

The key lies in structuring governance to respect sovereignty while enabling interoperability. Rather than a monolithic system controlled by any single nation, the infrastructure should function as a network of networks—allowing national systems to retain autonomy while connecting through standardized protocols. This federated model, similar to email or mobile roaming, preserves national control while unlocking network effects.

A Roadmap Forward

Implementation should proceed incrementally, beginning with a pilot program among willing nations. The Gulf Cooperation Council countries, given their existing economic integration and technological sophistication, represent an ideal starting point. Success here could demonstrate viability and attract broader participation.

The IsDB should commission a comprehensive feasibility study by Q2 2025, followed by the establishment of a technical working group including central banks, fintech companies, and Shariah scholars. A minimal viable product connecting five to seven countries could launch by 2027, with full OIC integration targeted for 2030.

Funding could come from a combination of IsDB capital, member state contributions proportional to GDP, and private sector investment attracted by transaction fee revenue. The system should be designed as a public utility rather than a profit-maximizing enterprise, with fees set to cover costs and fund continuous improvement.

"O you who have believed, fulfill all contracts" (Quran 5:1)

The Muslim world stands at a crossroads. It can continue accepting fragmentation and dependency in its financial infrastructure, or it can fulfill the contract of cooperation that faith and shared interest demand. The technology exists. The economic case is compelling. What remains is the political will to transform the OIC from a talking shop into a builder of shared prosperity. A unified digital payments system would not solve all economic challenges facing Muslim-majority nations, but it would represent a tangible step toward the economic dignity and self-sufficiency that 1.8 billion Muslims deserve.

articles.title: Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030: Seven Years of Economic Transformation Reveal Mixed Results
articles.author: Editorial Desk
articles.content:
A Bold Departure from Oil Dependency

When Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman unveiled Vision 2030 in April 2016, Saudi Arabia embarked on what many economists considered the most ambitious economic transformation programme in the modern Middle East. The kingdom, which had derived approximately 70% of its government revenue from oil exports, committed to reducing this dependency to 50% by 2030 while diversifying its economic base across tourism, entertainment, manufacturing, and financial services.

Seven years into this transformation, the results present a complex picture. Saudi Arabia's non-oil GDP grew by 4.5% in 2023, significantly outpacing the 1.1% contraction in oil GDP, according to the General Authority for Statistics. The non-oil sector now contributes approximately 50% to real GDP, up from 43% in 2016. Yet challenges persist: oil revenues still account for roughly 60% of government income, and youth unemployment remains elevated at 18.2% despite substantial job creation efforts.

The kingdom's approach reflects a particular interpretation of Islamic economic stewardship—the concept of istikhlaf (vicegerency), which emphasizes responsible management of resources for current and future generations. As the Quran states: "It is He who has made you successors upon the earth" (35:39). This theological framework underpins Vision 2030's emphasis on sustainability and long-term economic resilience rather than short-term extraction.

Infrastructure and Megaprojects: Building Tomorrow's Economy

The kingdom has committed over $1 trillion to infrastructure and megaprojects, with NEOM—the $500 billion futuristic city project—serving as the flagship initiative. The Public Investment Fund (PIF), Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, has grown from $150 billion in assets in 2015 to approximately $700 billion in 2024, making it one of the world's ten largest sovereign funds.

Beyond NEOM, the Red Sea Project aims to position Saudi Arabia as a luxury tourism destination, targeting 100 million annual visitors by 2030 compared to 18 million in 2019. The kingdom issued 13.5 million tourist visas in 2023, a substantial increase that reflects the opening of the umrah pilgrimage to year-round visits and the introduction of tourist visas for non-religious travel in 2019.

The entertainment sector, virtually non-existent before 2016, now contributes approximately $24 billion to GDP. The kingdom has hosted Formula 1 races, major boxing matches, and international music festivals—developments that would have been unthinkable a decade ago. The General Entertainment Authority reports that household spending on entertainment reached 6% of total expenditure in 2023, up from less than 1% in 2016.

However, these megaprojects face significant challenges. NEOM's ambitious timeline has been repeatedly adjusted, and questions persist about the economic viability of building entire cities in desert regions with limited water resources. Construction costs have escalated due to global inflation, and some international contractors have expressed concerns about payment delays and project scope changes.

Financial Sector Reforms and Capital Market Development

Saudi Arabia's financial sector has undergone substantial transformation, with the Tadawul stock exchange emerging as the largest in the Middle East with a market capitalization exceeding $3 trillion. The Saudi Aramco IPO in 2019, which raised $29.4 billion, remains the world's largest public offering and demonstrated the kingdom's commitment to capital market deepening.

The development of Islamic finance infrastructure has been particularly noteworthy. Saudi Arabia's sukuk market has grown to $140 billion outstanding, making it the second-largest globally after Malaysia. The kingdom issued its first sovereign sukuk in 2017 and has since become a regular issuer, with Islamic bonds now representing approximately 40% of total government debt issuance.

This emphasis on sukuk reflects the principle of avoiding riba (interest-based transactions) while accessing capital markets—a balance that Vision 2030 explicitly embraces. The Capital Market Authority has licensed several new Islamic financial institutions and created regulatory frameworks for innovative Shariah-compliant products, including Islamic REITs and green sukuk.

The Saudi Central Bank (SAMA) has also modernized payment systems, with digital payments growing from 18% of total transactions in 2016 to 67% in 2023. The fintech sector has attracted over $2 billion in investment since 2020, with Riyadh positioning itself as a regional fintech hub to compete with Dubai and Bahrain.

Labor Market Transformation and Saudization Challenges

Perhaps the most socially significant aspect of Vision 2030 is Saudization—the effort to reduce dependency on expatriate labor and increase private sector employment for Saudi nationals. The kingdom has implemented quota systems, sector-specific nationalization requirements, and wage subsidies through the Human Resources Development Fund.

Female labor force participation has increased dramatically from 17% in 2016 to 36% in 2023, representing one of Vision 2030's clearest successes. Reforms allowing women to drive, travel independently, and work in previously restricted sectors have unlocked significant economic potential. The McKinsey Global Institute estimates that achieving gender parity in workforce participation could add $90 billion to Saudi GDP by 2030.

However, overall Saudization targets remain elusive. While Saudi employment in the private sector increased from 1.2 million in 2016 to 2.1 million in 2023, expatriates still comprise approximately 80% of private sector workers. Many Saudi nationals continue to prefer public sector positions, which offer higher salaries, better job security, and shorter working hours—creating a structural mismatch that wage subsidies alone cannot resolve.

The Islamic principle of kasb (earning through one's own effort) emphasizes the dignity of productive work across all sectors. Vision 2030's challenge is cultivating this ethos while managing a generational transition in work culture and expectations.

Regional Comparison and Future Outlook

Compared to regional peers, Saudi Arabia's diversification progress is significant but uneven. The UAE's non-oil sector contributes approximately 70% to GDP, while Qatar and Kuwait remain more oil-dependent at around 45% and 35% non-oil GDP contribution respectively. Saudi Arabia's position in the middle of this spectrum reflects both its progress and remaining challenges.

The kingdom's fiscal position has strengthened, with the budget deficit declining from 15% of GDP in 2016 to an estimated 2% in 2024, aided by higher oil prices and improved non-oil revenue collection. However, the breakeven oil price—the price needed to balance the budget—remains elevated at approximately $80 per barrel, limiting fiscal flexibility if energy prices decline.

Looking forward, Vision 2030's success will depend on several factors: maintaining political stability while implementing social reforms, attracting sustained foreign direct investment beyond initial megaproject commitments, developing competitive advantages in new sectors beyond low-cost energy, and managing the environmental implications of rapid construction and development in water-scarce regions.

The kingdom's economic transformation reflects a broader understanding of tawhid (divine unity) as applied to economic development—recognizing that true prosperity requires balance across social, environmental, and economic dimensions rather than single-minded resource extraction. Whether Vision 2030 achieves its ambitious targets remains uncertain, but Saudi Arabia has undeniably embarked on a transformation whose effects will shape the Gulf region for decades to come.

articles.title: Indonesia's Ascent: How the World's Largest Muslim Nation Is Reshaping Global Islamic Finance
articles.author: Editorial Desk
articles.content:
From Regional Player to Global Contender

Indonesia's Islamic finance sector has entered a transformative phase, with the world's largest Muslim-majority nation positioning itself as a formidable competitor to established hubs in the Gulf Cooperation Council. With total Islamic banking assets reaching IDR 645 trillion (USD 41.2 billion) as of late 2023, Indonesia now commands approximately 1.8% of the global Islamic finance market—a figure that understates the nation's strategic importance given its demographic weight of 231 million Muslims, nearly 13% of the global Islamic population.

The archipelago's ambitions extend far beyond mere market share. Indonesia's Financial Services Authority (OJK) has orchestrated a comprehensive strategy that leverages the nation's unique advantages: a massive domestic market, growing middle class with purchasing power exceeding USD 1.2 trillion, and a government committed to developing Sharia-compliant financial infrastructure. This combination has attracted attention from international institutions, with the Islamic Development Bank committing USD 5 billion in financing for Indonesian projects through 2025, recognizing Jakarta's potential to become what Dubai is to the Middle East—a gateway for Islamic finance innovation.

Structural Reforms Driving Growth

The merger of three state-owned Islamic banks—Bank BRI Syariah, Bank Syariah Mandiri, and BNI Syariah—into Bank Syariah Indonesia (BSI) in February 2021 marked a watershed moment. With combined assets of IDR 239.3 trillion (USD 15.3 billion) at launch, BSI instantly became the seventh-largest Islamic bank globally, creating an institution with the scale necessary to compete internationally. The consolidation reflects a pragmatic understanding that fragmentation undermines competitiveness; prior to the merger, Indonesia had over a dozen Islamic banks, none commanding sufficient market presence to drive industry standards.

Beyond banking consolidation, Indonesia has developed a sophisticated sukuk market that now ranks among the world's most active. The government has issued sovereign sukuk worth over USD 50 billion cumulatively since 2008, with international issuances consistently oversubscribed. In 2023, Indonesia's USD 3 billion global sukuk offering attracted orders exceeding USD 11 billion, demonstrating robust international appetite. These instruments have financed critical infrastructure—from toll roads to renewable energy projects—while adhering to principles that prohibit riba (usury) and promote risk-sharing, embodying the Quranic directive: "Allah has permitted trade and forbidden riba" (2:275).

The nation's regulatory framework has matured considerably. The OJK's Sharia banking roadmap 2023-2027 targets 20% market share for Islamic banking within the domestic financial sector, up from approximately 7% currently. This includes mandates for improved digital infrastructure, standardized product offerings, and enhanced Sharia governance. Indonesia has also pioneered innovative instruments like the retail sukuk program, which has attracted over 100,000 individual investors, democratizing access to Islamic finance beyond institutional players.

The Halal Economy Multiplier Effect

Indonesia's Islamic finance ambitions are inseparable from its broader halal economy strategy, valued at USD 218 billion domestically in 2023. The government has designated halal certification, Islamic tourism, and modest fashion as priority sectors, each requiring Sharia-compliant financing mechanisms. This creates a virtuous cycle: as halal industries expand, demand for Islamic financial products grows, which in turn provides capital for further halal sector development.

The numbers tell a compelling story. Indonesia's halal food and beverage sector alone generated USD 170 billion in 2023, making it the world's largest halal market. Yet only 15% of halal-certified businesses currently utilize Islamic banking services, representing a vast untapped opportunity. Financial institutions are responding with specialized products: BSI launched a halal supply chain financing program that has disbursed over IDR 12 trillion (USD 765 million) to certified halal producers, while smaller Islamic banks have developed microfinance products targeting the 64 million micro-enterprises in Indonesia's informal economy.

This approach aligns with Islamic economic principles emphasizing maqasid al-shariah—the objectives of Islamic law that prioritize human welfare, economic justice, and equitable wealth distribution. As the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) stated: "The upper hand is better than the lower hand," encouraging economic self-sufficiency through productive enterprise rather than dependency.

Challenges and Regional Competition

Despite impressive progress, Indonesia faces formidable challenges. Malaysia, with Islamic banking assets of USD 238 billion (representing 38% of its total banking sector), maintains a significant lead in both scale and sophistication. Malaysian institutions benefit from decades of regulatory refinement, extensive Sharia scholarship infrastructure, and established international networks. The United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, meanwhile, leverage enormous capital reserves and geographic proximity to global financial centers.

Indonesia's Islamic finance penetration rate of 7% lags behind Malaysia (38%), Saudi Arabia (51%), and even neighboring Brunei (64%). This reflects persistent challenges: limited public awareness, insufficient Sharia-literate financial professionals (Indonesia has approximately 400 certified Sharia advisors compared to Malaysia's 1,200), and competition from deeply entrenched conventional banking. The World Bank estimates that 86 million Indonesian adults remain unbanked, representing both opportunity and challenge for Islamic financial inclusion.

Infrastructure gaps also constrain growth. Indonesia's digital payment infrastructure, while improving rapidly, still reaches only 68% of the population, limiting the effectiveness of fintech-driven Islamic banking solutions. Regulatory harmonization across the archipelago's 34 provinces remains incomplete, creating compliance complexities for institutions seeking national scale.

The Path Forward: Innovation and Integration

Indonesia's strategy for the next phase emphasizes technological innovation and regional integration. The country has become a hotbed for Islamic fintech, with over 150 Sharia-compliant digital platforms operating as of 2024. Companies like Alami and Ammana have pioneered peer-to-peer financing models that connect Muslim investors with halal businesses, disbursing over IDR 8 trillion (USD 510 million) collectively. The OJK has created regulatory sandboxes specifically for Islamic fintech, recognizing that digital channels may prove decisive in reaching Indonesia's geographically dispersed population.

Regionally, Indonesia has championed ASEAN-level Islamic finance integration, proposing standardized Sharia governance frameworks and cross-border sukuk issuance mechanisms. The nation hosted the Indonesia Sharia Economic Festival in 2023, attracting over 50,000 participants and USD 2.8 billion in investment commitments. Such initiatives position Indonesia as a thought leader, not merely a market participant.

The ultimate vision extends beyond financial metrics to embody Islamic economic principles of falah (prosperity) and adalah (justice). As Indonesia's Islamic finance sector matures, it offers a model for how populous Muslim-majority nations can build financial systems that serve both economic development and religious values—a balance increasingly relevant as global interest in ethical finance grows. With GDP projected to reach USD 1.6 trillion by 2025 and a young, digitally-savvy Muslim population, Indonesia's emergence as a global Islamic finance hub appears not a question of if, but when.
